summary: an RNA triphosphatase, a guanylyltransferase, and a guanine-N7-methyltransferase (N7-MTase) are used in viral and eukaryotic cellular mRNAs. the basic cap-0 structure m7GpppN is formed by sequential reactions catalyzed by an RNA triphosphatase, a guanylyltransferase, and coronavirus currently consists of four virus families, Arteriviridae (12.7- to 15.7-kb genomes; known as small-genome nidoviruses), Coronaviridae, Roniviridae, and the recently recognized Mesoniviridae (26.3 to 31.7 kb) the last three families are known as large-genome nidoviruses. nidovirus is the type species of the genus Okavirus in the family Roniviridae of the order Nidovirales. it has been associated with mortalities in black tiger shrimps (Penaeus monodon) and economic losses to shrimp farming in eastern Australia. nidoviruses may have evolved from arthropods, according to bioinformatics analysis. all nidoviruses except arteriviruses encode a 2′-O-MTase domain at the C-terminal end of their large pp1ab replicase polyprotein. all large-genome nidoviruses except toroviruses possess an N7-MTase domain. ronivirus nsp16 possesses 2′-O-MTase activity in vitro. this is in contrast with coronavirus nsp16, which requires virus-encoded nsp10 as a cofactor for its full function. these results extend our understanding of nidovirus RNA capping and methylation. pGEX-6p-1-GAV nsp10 and pGEX-6p-1-GAV nsp16 were cloned into the genome. the mutant plasmids of pGEX-6p-1-GAV nsp16 were generated by one-step PCR with mutagenic primers. pET30a-EToV nsp16 (pp1ab residues 6593 to 6857; 265 aa) was cloned into E. coli expression vectors pET30a and pGEX-6p-1. pET30a-EToV nsp16 was expressed and purified similarly to GAV nsp16. the cells were grown in LB medium containing kanamycin at 37°C. the bacterial cells were harvested by centrifugation and lysed by sonication.
